title: 108_hr261
content: The Act titled "Stop Discrimination Against Seven States Act of 2003" allows residents of states with no income tax to deduct state and local general sales taxes. The Act "Stop Discrimination Against Seven States Act of 2003" permits residents of states without income tax to deduct state and local general sales taxes. The Act "Stop Discrimination Against Seven States Act of 2003" allows residents of states without income tax to deduct state and local general sales taxes imposed at one rate on a broad range of items, excluding specific categories like food, clothing, medical supplies, and motor vehicles. The Act allows residents of certain states to deduct state and local general sales taxes imposed at one rate on a broad range of items, excluding specific categories like food, clothing, medical supplies, and motor vehicles. Items taxed at different rates may not be deducted, except for items with a lower tax rate described in the Act. The Act allows residents in certain states to deduct state and local general sales taxes imposed on a wide range of items, excluding specific categories like food, clothing, medical supplies, and motor vehicles. Compensating use taxes on items are treated as general sales taxes if they meet certain criteria, including being complementary to a general sales tax. The general rate of tax shall be treated as the rate of tax if excess is disregarded. Separately stated general sales taxes paid by the consumer to the seller are treated as taxes paid by the consumer. The deduction amount is determined under tables prescribed by the Secretary. The Secretary prescribes tables reflecting provisions for average taxpayer consumption on a State-by-State basis, considering filing status, dependents, income, and sales tax rates. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after the date of the enactment of this Act, with respect to adjusted gross incomes up to the applicable amount determined under section 68(b).
